title: xx
story: Sick crimes of Toy Box Killer who put dog collars on victims before torturing themWarning: This story contains some distressing details about sexual assault. A suspected serial killer who evaded police for decades was given the nickname Toy Box Killer after kitting out a trailer with torture devices and holding women as "sex slaves"David Parker Rayand his lawyer Jeff Rein at the  trial Image: Getty ImagesByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsCynthia Vigil was just  years old when she was arrested by an undercover cop for soliciting sex illegally in a car park in . But after she was handcuffed by the mysterious officer, it didnapost take long for Cynthia to realise something was seriously wrong. Before she could resist, Cynthia was tasered, drugged and blindfolded. When she woke up, she was chained to a bed. This was when it became clear to the then sex worker that she hadnapost been arrested - sheaposd been abducted. The man who had kidnapped Cynthia was David Parker Ray, a sadistic serial rapist and torturer - who is suspected to have killed several women in his home state of New Mexico, US. Ray, who kept diaries including details of his victims, owned a repurposed trailer that heaposd soundproofed and kitted out with torture devices. And when his depraved crimes were finally revealed, they horried the community around him. Early le of a monster Ray, born in , was primarily raised by his grandparents who were believed to have run a strict, religious household. Growing up, Ray and his sister Peggy were sporadically visited by their violent, alcoholic father.  As the siblings grew up in a tiny rural town, Peggy became a popular, outgoing girl - while Ray remained shy and something of a loner. Although he didnapost have many friends at school and spent lots of time on his own, Ray wasnapost considered a troublemaker but showed signs of weird behaviour in childhood. From an early age heaposs believed to have taken an interest in pornography and violence, which he hid from those around him. It is also reported that Ray developed a fetish for broken bottles, keeping a stash of them in a dungeon heaposd built in the woods when he was . But after reaching adolescence, he lived a seemingly normal le and joined the US Army, receiving an honourable discharge at the end of his enlistment. Family and fatherhood Over the years Ray married several times and fathered lots of children, but he abandoned his families and only really bonded with a daughter he had - Glenda Jean Ray. Described as a Daddyaposs girl, Glenda Jean idolised her father and the pair were incredibly close as she got older. Their bond was even more unusual given that Ray had abandoned Glenda Jean, her mother and her siblings when they were young to live on the road and eventually adopt a hippy lestyle.  But just a few years later, he ed to Glenda Jeanaposs mum, who took him back. As Rayaposs beloved daughter developed into an adult she was tall, slim and blonde - looking much like a younger version of her dad. She also changed her name several times, going by Jessy to most people she knew. The relationship between Ray and Jessyaposs mum lasted another decade before he moved on to other women - including Cindy Hendy, who became his accomplice. The aposToy Boxapos To carry out his sick crimes, Ray bought an old trailer and converted it into a Toy Box, which included soundproofing and installing a gynaecological chair to strap victims into. The ceiling of the trailer was lined with mirrors, meaning the victims watched in horror at the torture he was inflicting on them. The rest of the Toy Box was kitted out with chains, whips, straps, clamps, saws and sex toys. Perhaps most disturbingly, the walls of the torture chamber were adorned with diagrams showing dferent methods of inflicting pain.  Ray is thought to have had several accomplices who helped him commit his unthinkable crimes, including friends and even girlfriends. When he was finally caught and the FBI raided the trailer, they found disturbing audio tapes heaposd recorded in which he told victims what was about to happen to them. One recording recovered reportedly told a victim she was going to be raped thoroughly and repeatedly, telling her she was a sex slave. Cynthiaaposs escape After kidnapping an unknown number of victims, Ray was finally caught in  when Cynthia Vigil escaped the Toy Box. She had spent three days chained to the gynaecologistaposs table in the torture trailer by Ray and three accomplices - girlfriend Cindy, daughter Jessy and friend Dennis Yancy. Seizing her opportunity for freedom after Ray had gone to work, Cynthia managed to grab the keys to her chains after Cindy left them on a nearby table. While she was unlocking herself, Cindy walked back into the room and a fight broke out between the two. But Cynthia managed to stab Hendy in the neck with an ice pick and make her escape.  Completely naked save for chains and a dog collar and covered in Cindyaposs blood, Cynthia fled and tried to flag down a passing car, before finding a house she considered safe and running inside. The homeowner covered her up and called the police. When they arrived, Cynthia recalled the gruesome tale and led cops to the location of the trailer. Ray and Hendy were swtly arrested - leading two other women to come forward claiming they had also been kidnapped and tortured by the sadist. Police investigations identied Jessy and Dennis Yancy as accomplices to the crimes - with Yancy admitting to murdering his girlfriend Marie Parker after Ray had kidnapped and tortured her. Trials and death Rayaposs attacks were separated into three trials for each woman who came forward against him. After the first trial had to be repeated, Ray was convicted of  counts of torture and sexual assault. The victim in the second trial sadly died before she could see justice, meaning no verdict was ever made. Eventually in , Ray was sentenced to  years in prison for ious offences in the abduction and torture of his victims. He was soon dubbed the Toy Box Killer as cops believed he was responsible for up to  murders - but no bodies relating to his crimes were ever recovered. Jessy Ray was given a sentence of nine years while Cindy Hendy was given  years in prison. On  May , Ray was taken to a facility in New Mexico to be questioned by state police. Shortly before the interrogation took place, he had a heart attack and died. Since managing to escape from the Toy Box, Cynthia Vigil has gone on to have a family, but she has shared her story in the hope other victims of evil Ray will come forward. Recalling her ordeal to reporters in , she said: This was a very sick man. The only thing that gives me any comfort is that he’s gone. If I didn’t get away, I wouldn’t have my three wonderful boys. I wouldn’t be here. title: bamboo plant causes devastating 100000
story: Bamboo plant causes devastating £, damage to horried neighbours homeBamboo planted at a Hampshire home somehow grew under the neighbours property and broke through its concrete floor - causing a huge £, worth of damageThe only way to solve the problem was to dig up the ground floor of the Hampshire house Image: Environet UKByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsHomeowners have been issued an urgent warning after a home faced £, worth of damage caused by a running bamboo plant.Bamboo was planted at the property to form some of the border hedge, but allegedly it was left unmonitored and grew as a result.The plantaposs roots grew underneath the next door home and broke through its concrete floor. It then continued to grow through the propertyaposs cavity walls and eventually it would have forced the walls apartit hadnapost been tackled. The only way to solve the problem was to dig up the ground floor of the Hampshire house and remove hundreds of metres of bamboo rhizomes. The home insurance claim for the damage was apparently more than £,, reports the Express.Japanese Knotweed is famously a nightmare, but experts have said bamboo can be just as baditaposs left to grow unmonitored. The roots of bamboo can travel up to a whopping  metres and they can break through all sorts of surfaces, from bricks and drains to cavity walls and patios.  aposRunningapos ieties of bamboo like the one found at the Hampshire property are particularly prolic as they send lateral shoots out underneath the ground which can sometimes pop up on neighboursapos plots. Founder and MD of Environet UK, Nic Seal, told the Sun: Through no fault of their own, the homeowners have suffered signicant financial cost, stress and inconvenience, being required to vacate their home for several months. The truth is, most bamboos are invasiveplanted directly into the ground and left to their own devices. He added that the Hampshire case was the worst case of bamboo encroachment heaposd ever seen in this country. Experts advise itaposs best to choose a clumping iety of bamboo rather than a running iety to avoid spreading problems like these. Those buying bamboo should also plant it in a pot instead of in the ground and make sure to trim it frequently. title: catcalling unacceptable needs taken seriously
story: Catcalling is unacceptable - it needs to be taken seriously once and for allBradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcallingImage: Getty Images AlloyopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Feb |commentsIt probably seems like a small thing, at best. At worst, a waste of time and resources. It’s not though. It’s important. A tiny triumph. A baby step in the right direction. Bradford Police have launched an undercover operation to combat catcalling – “targeting people who are shouting things from their vehicles at women girls. This will not be tolerated.” Last week they stopped a van after the occupant yelled at some women who turned out to be plain-clothed police officers. Oh to have seen his face. He was reported for a breach of the Public Spaces Protection Order and is likely to be issued with a £ fine or taken to court, which is another way of saying that he was left in no doubt that THIS IS NOT OK. That’s apparently what men need to be told, reminded of, in no uncertain terms, so they’re one hundred per cent clear. No, it’s not just a bit of harmless fun that we need to lighten up about. It’s horrendous. Scary. Humiliating.  Maybe this concept is confusing because we’re living in an age of sharing, honesty, and talking about everything. Mostly that’s great, but somewhere within this, a simple truth has got lost. Sometimes, it’s good NOT to talk. Sometimes, you need to shut the hell up. Perhaps we need a massive advertising campaign, public service announcement telly commercials and posters everywhere to clearly inform everyone once and for all: Stop telling women what you think of their bodies. Especially when they haven’t asked, which is pretty much always. There are no Thought Police – anyone is free to think whatever they like. The opinions inside someone’s head can’t hurt anyone . The problem comes when they’re broadcast out loud to the woman you’re thinking them about, be it on the street, online, or on a radio show, like that fool who talked about Strictly’s Tilly Ramsay. What you think of the woman’s body is irrelevant, by the way. Evenyou believe it’s a compliment, still keep it to yourself. Of course there are exceptions to the rule, but most women do not feel flattered and delighted when a stranger gives them positive feedback about a body part. We feel embarrassed, and frightened. And we’re taught to ignore this behaviour – apart from in Bradford, it’s up to us to deal with it ourselves – to put our heads down, walk quicker, in case the situation escalates.We’re luckywe are only verbally harassed. Even online, where the threat of physical violence is removed, these kind of comments are dangerous, and unacceptable. They perpetuate the belief that women’s appearances are fair game for discussion and debate. That our bodies are anyone’s business but our own. They also ensure that the practice of speaking about women in this way seeps down to future generations, continuing the cycle. It has to stop. As the fight to make our streets safer for women goes on, catcalling being taken seriously in one city in the UK is just a drop in the ocean. But at least it’s a start. Maybe those TV ads aren’t a bad idea – and it’s obvious what music they should be set to. Ronan Keating, You Say It Best, When You Say Nothing At All. title: couple lose 50000 after cowboy
story: Couple lose £, after cowboy builder walks off saying he doesnt need the stressJames Bradshaw said his family were left living on a building site in Wolverhampton after their builder walked off the job and a survey later showed all his work needed to be demolishedThe house was left with a half-finished extension after the builder walked off the job, saying he didnt need the stress Image: Kennedy News and MediaByRebecca CooleyJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  A devastated couple say they have lost their £, le savings and been left living on a building site thanks to a cowboy builderaposs half-finished extension which then had to be demolished. James Bradshaw, , says the builder, who heaposd hired to add a two-storey extension to their house, would only work five-hour days and when confronted about his shoddy workmanship brazenly quit saying he didnapost want the stress .The couple agreed to pay almost £, to the builder, who came recommended by a family friend, for an extension to accommodate their growing family, a job that was supposed to be completed by August . But after months of issues and delays the builder vanished in September, leaving James and his family £, out of pocket and living on a building site. The -year-old says he has since had a surveyor assess the work that had been done, who concluded that it needed to be completely demolished and restarted due to structural issues. When James contacted a solicitor he was advised not to bother taking the builder to court as he wonapost see a penny of his hard-earned savings again - evenhe wins the case.  The sales director has now shared photos of the mess heaposs been left with in a bid to warn other conscientious and decent peopleapos not to fall victim to cowboy builders. James, from Wolverhampton, said: The reason we were having the extension done is because weaposve had a daughter and we have three children living with us already - my son and my fianceaposs two children. We were having the extension done to create two extra bedrooms and to extend the kitchen and dining room to have a bit more space for the kids. It was shocking from day one. He never did a full week, heaposd only turn up two to three times a weekat all and heaposd turn up at :am and leave at pm. Every time the building inspector came to review the work heaposd done it kept getting failed so he had to redo lots of it. Eventually I said to him aposyou need to come in for a meeting because this just isnapost good enoughapos. As he walked through the door he said aposIaposm going to give you your money back and you can get someone  to complete it because I canapost get it done and I donapost want the stress anymoreapos. He only offered us £, back and I just said aposyouaposre a joke and youaposll be hearing from our solicitoraposs. He left our house in the state itaposs in and we havenapost spoken to him since. Itaposs been a nightmare. Itaposs put a lot of strain on mine and my partneraposs le and caused a lot of devastation for our family. Weaposd been saving the money for about  years and weaposd got a loan to help as well which weaposre still paying back at the minute.  The two-storey extension was supposed to create two extra bedrooms and an extended kitchen and dining area within  weeks, for an agreed cost of £,. By the time of their final meeting in September - two months after the extension was supposed to be finished - there was only an incomplete single-storey and a plank of wood blocking where the back door used to be. The following month, an independent building survey confirmed that what was built was plagued with structural issues and needed to be completely demolished and restarted, despite the parents already forking out a whopping £,. The report found that the walls were out of square in numerous places and either had a cavity that was too wide or cavity ties that were too short. This means they werenapost fully tied in and didnapost provide full stability. It also noted that the entire structure was at risk of damp due to multiple issues, including mortar breaching the wall cavities, and aposlazy workmanshipapos was evident in the internal brickwork, where a broken brick aposlooked to have been jammed in placeapos. Overall the report concluded: Considering the overall condition of the build we would recommend that it is removed down to foundation level and the structure started again. Demolishing the work alone would cost an additional £. In light of this, James sought legal advice to try and claw back some of his hard-earned savings back to be able to recty the nightmare build.  But the dad says that his solicitor then delivered the devastating news that although he would definitely win in court he would never see a penny of the £, again because the builder could simply close the business down due to not having the funds to repay it. James said: I had a meeting with the solicitor and said aposdonapost tell me what I want to hear, tell me the honest truthapos. Her words were aposthe only person that wins in this is the solicitors because we get paid either way, itaposs going to cost you £, to £, to go to courtapos. She said aposyou will win in court but his solicitor will advise him to shut the company down because he hasnapost got the money to pay it back so you wonapost see a pennyapos.Two days after we received the court letter it came up on Facebook that the company was closed so I think heaposs already shut it down. Weaposve looked into his history a bit now as well and heaposs well known for opening companies and shutting them down - I think this is the fourth company heaposs done that with since . The family had new builders start at their home last week to demolish the unstable structure and restart the extension. But at a new estimated cost of £,, they can no longer afford to get much of the project done. The heartbroken dad hopes that by warning people about the dishonest and unreliable cowboy he fell victim to, he can help other families avoid the same fate. James said: Thereaposs nothing we can do now, we just have to bite the bullet that weaposre not going to get anything from it because the system doesnapost support this kind of thing. Weaposve got new builders in now but because weaposve wasted so much money we can only afford to get the shell done and weaposll have to do the inside stage by stage. The new quote to put right and finish it is £, because thereaposs been a huge increase in prices of building materials and labour as well as the extra work of demolishing it. title: cruel neglectful pandemic puppy farmer
story: Cruel, neglectful pandemic puppy farmer jailed after breaking lelong dog banJeremy Awdry was sentenced to  weeks imprisonment after he admitted breaches of the dog ban, just months after it was imposedAwdry kept the puppies in squalid conditions at his home Image: Gloucestershire News ServiceByMirror:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  A -year-old puppy farmer branded “cruel” and “neglectful” when he was convicted in court last year and disqualied from keeping dogs for le has been jailed for flouting the ban.Jeremy Awdry, of Bream, Gloucestershire - a sheep owner with commoners rights in the Forest of Dean - was sentenced yesterday to  weeks imprisonment after he admitted breaches of the dog ban, just months after it was imposed. Prosecutor Sara Anthony told Cheltenham Magistrates Court that a year ago Awdry was disqualied for le from owning, keeping, transporting or being in any way involved with dogs. The ban was imposed in February  at Gloucester Crown Court after Awdry and two other defendants were convicted for selling puppies without a licence, and failing to meet the needs of the animals. The puppies were kept in squalid conditions at Awdryaposs home and were poorly looked after. Awdry and his two accomplices were estimated to have made £, from puppy farming over four years. Yesterday, Ms Anthony told the court that the Forest of Dean District Council was tipped off that Awdry was still using dogs for work and had been seen transporting his dogs about, shortly after his dog ban was imposed. On April ,  at .am two members of the councilaposs street warden team were in the Bream area and were travelling along Oakwood Road when they spotted Awdry in a white Nissan vehicle beside a five bar gate,” Ms Anthony said. “They both had a clear view of a black and white Collie sitting on the front passenger seat. They watched Awdry turn the vehicle around and drive to the other side of the field and park alongside an outbuilding. They both saw Awdry unload two Collie dogs from the vehicle and usher them towards the outbuilding. Awdry was then observed ing to his vehicle without the dogs. Awdry drove down Highfield Close and disappeared from the area. The street wardens checked the outbuilding and observed that the two dogs were inside. While the wardens were making notes of what they had just witnessed Awdry ed in his van accompanied by his we. He parked beside the outbuilding and opened the door while Mrs Awdry encouraged the dogs into the vehicle from the passenger side. Awdry ed to the vehicle and drove off. On the second occasion the district council was contacted by PC Katherine McDay who was driving in a marked vehicle from Coleford to Bream on May  last year at around pm when she noticed Awdryaposs Nissan van on the B near the area of Bream Cross. She noticed a large amount of sheep coming from a field opposite. Pc McDay travelled past the Nissan and turned around. While she travelled back towards the van she noticed that Awdry was driving and his we was in the passenger seat with a black Collie dog on her lap. As Pc McDay passed she noticed that the dog was released out of the passenger door and it began herding sheep along the road. A short while later she noticed Awdry drive away from the area and saw that the sheep were no longer visible. The dog had its head out of the passenger window. Clive Rees, defending, said: I feel that Awdry did not fully understand the rules surrounding the disqualication order. He was under the impression thathe had somebody with him who was responsible for the dogs he would be complying with the terms of the order. Awdry had already transferred ownership of the dogs to his we. He has kept dogs all his le and, being a commoner, he has the right to roam sheep on the common. He frequently gets calls from police to remove them from the road, eventhey are not his own sheep. When the order was initially issued Awdry would get his we to drive his van with the dogs. However over the past few months Mrs Awdryaposs health has deteriorated and she has recently lost much of her eyesight and most of her hearing. Mr Awdry has become her carer. Awdry started the order with good intentions. His son has now taken over the responsibility for the dogs. Whoever saw the dogs, there was no mention of them being concerned about the animalsapos welfare. In the future Awdry will have to come to terms about not looking after sheep in future. He realises now that he is in a serious position. He should have known the position when he was sentenced at Gloucester Crown Court. Awdry pleaded guilty to breaching a disqualication order imposed after conviction on two occasions. On or around April ,  at Lydney, having been previously disqualied from keeping dogs he transported two black and white collie dogs inside a white Nissan white van, and on May ,  he transported a black and white collie dog inside the same van whilst directing  sheep to exit a field and move along the B Rd heading towards Bream. Presiding Justice Major Paul Adey sentenced Awdry to six weeks imprisonment for the two offences of transporting dogs and activated the  week suspended sentence consecutively. We note that the dogs are no longer in your and Mrs Awdryaposs ownership, a move which should have been undertaken  months ago, said the magistrate. “We also acknowledge that the dogs have not been mistreated whilst they have been in your care. The justices ordered that outstanding court costs of £, and the £, costs of yesterdayaposs case must be paid by Awdry by th April this year. After yesterdayaposs hearing Forest of Dean District Councilaposs Animal Welfare Member Champion, Councillor Nicky Packer said Our Street Warden team do a fantastic job year round of ensuring that animals in our district are looked after properly, and that those who mistreat or cause harm to their animals are held accountable.” This verdict should stand as testament to this. A ban on keeping dogs means exactly that. If, as in this case, it isnapost followed, our Street Warden and Counter Fraud and Enforcement team will enforce it. A council spokesperson added The prosecution was undertaken by Forest of Dean District Councilaposs Legal Services team working with the Councilaposs Street Wardens Team and Counter Fraud and Enforcement Unit . title: im professional cuddler make 1500
story: Im a professional cuddler - I make £, a month hugging strangers in my bedKristiina Link, , from east London is a certied ‘cuddle therapist,’ offering hugs to those feeling lonely and isolated, with her sessions lasting up to three hours at a timeThe -year-old holds sessions up to three hours long Image: MERCURY PRESSByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsCuddling strangers is a real job - and it will net you thousands of pounds.One woman has revealed how she makes thousands by hugging and spooning strangers - rather than your standard desk job.Kristiina Link, , from Stratford, East London, has turned a pastime into a job - and even earns up to £ per snuggling session. Her services include handholding, hair stroking and embracing her clients for up to three hours at a time.The therapist says there are many emotional benefits to the practice - and her boyfriend understands the unique demands of her job.After a breakup, heartbroken Kristiina decided to take a snuggle training course to combat her loneliness.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter hereShe said: “In , I was missing the cuddling and affectionate side of a relationship after becoming single.“I thought that there should be a service where people help each other and cuddle – Itaposs a bit like Uber for cuddles.“Hugs release the love hormone, oxytocin which is known to help with loneliness, anxiety and depression.“For this to be released, studies show that you need the hug to last at least  seconds but people normally hug for a few seconds, so they never experience the full effect.In my work, I see a lot of people who are feeling isolated because of the pandemic as well as those who are grieving and in need of physical comfort.After a y introductory process, Kristiina begins her sessions by playing meditative music and holding her clientsapos hands before cuddling up in a double bed.She said: I start by playing calming music, handholding and I encourage deep breathing so they feel present in the moment.We cuddle in multiple positions such as standing up and spooning but I change the position every  minutes otherwise arms get sore and people need to stretch.Some people are nervous at first or donapost like their hair and arms being stroked so boundaries are always discussed before we begin - itaposs important that people feel like theyaposre in a safe space and have been paired with the right person.Iaposm not a talking therapist, weaposre not trained to give advice however most people I see tend to receiving counselling or talking therapy as well as seeing me.Although it is becoming a recognised wellness trend, Kristiina says people often have a misconception about her occupation.She said: “It’s still a fairly new concept so some people get confused about what cuddle therapy actually is - It was the same for professional massages fty years ago.Mainly men visit because women tend to be touchier with their girlfriend and in general men donapost have many male friends.“I get a lot of men who work in managerial positions who want to unwind after talking and being in charge all day.Kristina sees clients who are over , however her main clients are aged between  and  years old.She said: “I see a few younger men, who are still quite shy – they might have low confidence and want to explore how to connect with a female through cuddling and touch.“I usually see single clients but there are some who are in a relationship whose partner doesn’t like cuddling or they don’t have touch love language.It is sad to hear but cuddling can teach them ways to connect with their partner and they can take these techniques back to their relationship.As well as getting her own dose of the aposloveapos hormone, Kristiina receives up to £ for her affectionate services.She said: “A one-hour session costs £ however I offer appointments for up to three hours and I apply a £ discount with those.You release the cuddling chemicals over four hours but people start to get headaches and even drowsy at the end.Three hours is the optimalfor a cuddle as more than this can lead to drowsiness, headaches and even dehydration. Too much of anything isnapost good for you and that also goes for cuddling.Although she makes a fortune from those who are desperate to be touched, Kristinaaposs main passion is to help with peopleaposs emotional needs.I donapost set my prices as high as other cuddle therapists and I apply a lot of discounts so that everyone can experience the healing power of cuddle therapy.She adds: My clients understand that cuddling is a form of plutonic touch therapy however, I’ve had regular clients who come every week and I sometimes I see that as a sign they’re attached.If the client doesnapost switch between cuddlers, it can lead to an attachment in the long run which I want to avoid.Itaposs important that people come to the session with the right intention and in the consultation, I make sure that cuddle therapy is right for them. Now, Kristiina has been a cuddle therapist for three years and has found love with her new partner Matt, .Matt is thrilled that Kristiina has a career that makes her happy however she says that not many people have the same open-mindedness as her partner.She said: “Initially, my mum was terried - she was so concerned for my safety.“She then saw how happy it was making me and that I was doing really well in a safe space.These days, thereaposs a big community in London and itaposs becoming more normalised so people are becoming more curious about the benefits of healing touch.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Mental healthTherapy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ive no heating month cant
story: Exclusive: Ive had no heating for month as cant afford bills and food - I share bed with kids to stay warmMum-of-two Beth Connock, who is a full-time carer for her disabled son, has to share a bed with her children to keep them warm after a hike in the price of oil left them without heatingThe family have been left without heating for a month Image: Beth ConnockByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Feb |commentsSingle mum Beth Connock can no longer afford to keep the house warm AND feed her two children after her heating bills soared by  per cent. The -year-old mum of two - who is a full-time carer to disabled son Tommy, aged  - has now lived without heating for more than a month.“Itaposs really upsetting because I feel like a failure of a mother. I can choose between keeping my house warm at the moment and feeding the kids. “And the kids need to be fed but they need to be warm, it’s quite upsetting. No one should have to choose between feeding or eating.” Beth is one of the . million UK householders whose heating is powered by oil as her home in the rural hamlet of Dartshill, Somerset does not have a mains gas supply.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Her problem started as the cost to heat her family home, which she rents, rose sharply - from £ to £ for  litres, to fill less than half the tank.The cost of living crisis has left the mum, Tommy, five, and Gabby, three, forced to share a bed each night.They have a tiny electric heater to warm the bedroom they share, but in the evenings, they can see their breath in their living room when the temperature drops. Desperate to keep her children warm, Beth bundles them up in jumpers and scarves at home - but Tommy, who is autistic, struggles to wear the outfits. She says: “We’re wearing a lot of extra layers and having to sleep in the same bed to keep warm. “I shut the bedroom door to keep our body heat in but as soon as we got downstairs, it is freezing and we’re all shivering. “It’s a very old draughty cottage, I woke up the other morning around  am to find ice around the windowsill. “We’re wearing a lot more clothes, which means a lot more washing and a backlog of clothes as we wait days for things to dry. “It’s also a choice when it comes to hot water -the kids have a bath, I can’t have a shower as well.” She added: “I have no money and I’m worried about the kids getting ill because it is so cold. “February and March can be the coldest months so I needed to get something done quickly.” Tommy, aged five, is “very delayed” and has to wear specic clothes, meaning he doesn’t like wearing the extra layers.Beth is unable to work after becoming his full-time carer due to his severe epilepsy and the family rely on Universal Credit to get by.She previously tried to get a loan but was refused as she still owes around £ from the last loan she received. “I’ve tried everything. I even tried to get a grant in my local area but I heard nothing back,” the mum said. She also claims disability allowance to support him, who spent nine weeks in hospital in , suffering constant seizures. He has to wear a helmet to protect himselfhe falls, and mum Beth is on constant alert for his seizures. “Because of his epilepsy and autism, he is very delayed, and he doesn’t understand why we need to wear these extra clothes,” added Beth. “So trying to keep him warm it’s really dficult, he’s used to having heating and now we don’t have it. “It’s very frustrating for him.”  The desperate mum recently turned toGoFundMeto help cover the £ bill - where one kindhearted stranger donated £ anonymously.The hike in the price of oil comes amid a cost of living crisis with Beth’s rent recently rising by £ per month - a rise she will struggle to cover. Struggling Brits are bracing for further financial turmoil this spring - with tax rises, wage cuts and soaring bills set to batter household budgets further.The cost of living crisis could see families suffer a £, a year average hit, The Mirror exclusively revealed today - in a further blow to families such as Bethaposs.Low-income families are set to be the most affected by the crisis - with no spending they can cut back on. She said: “We scrape by every month, it’s dficult. With Universal Credit, I don’t knowthey’ll cover the rent increase. “As a single mum on benefits, £ is a lot of money. “Tommy’s school is about half an hour away so I do an hour-round journey every day to get him there. “It got to the point where I was desperate for heating and I just had to set up a GoFundMe page.” She plans to donate any excess to the Daisy Garland charity, that supported her family while Tommy was in the hospital.Donate to Beth’sGoFundMehere.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsOil pricesSingle mumEpilepsyAsperger’s syndromeEnergy bills" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man given days live after
story: Man given days to live after blood cancer symptoms dismissed as old age for  yearsRetired bus driver Brian Mellor, , from Blackpool, was found unable to move last year after bending down to wash his hands - he has since been diagnosed with cancerBrians cancer went undiagnosed for  years as doctors put symptoms down to old ageByRebecca LockwoodLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A retired bus driver nearly died after his incurable blood cancer went undiagnosed for  years after his symptoms were put down to old age.Brian Mellor, , from Blackpool, couldnapost move after his femur and hip had split open for no logical reason.Brianaposs daughter, Alyson Yates, , and husband Alan are planning weekly gigs throughout March to raise money for Myeloma UK which funds research into a cure which almost claimed her fatheraposs le last year, reports Lancashire Live.Doctors had reportedly dismissed Brianaposs previous symptoms, aches and pains as old age. Tests continued tonegative and the family felt nobody could explain what was wrong with him. Brian was found aposunable to moveapos on May  last year after bending down to wash his hands. Little did we know that our world was about to be blown apart, Alyson said. My dad suddenly was unable to move and we had to call an ambulance. It came to light that my dadaposs femur and hip had split open but there was no logical reason for this he hadnapost banged himself or had a fall. On the May  after much investigation it came to light that my dad had myeloma and was very poorly. He wasnapost even awake so I couldn’t tell him how much I loved him and that he had to fight. The next day, Alyson said she had to discuss a do-not-resuscitate order with her fatheraposs consultant. What a shocker, she said, we only found out about the cancer the day before and he only came into hospital  days before that. How can things be this bad so quick  May  was one of the worst days of our le, Alyson continued. We got a call to say come in, Dad wasnapost going to be pulling through, and would not make the weekend. To this point we had all been restricted to seeing my dad because of Covid but now we were allowed to be by his side. I cannot emphasise what a shock this week had been to us all. How quick the tide had turned in our le. What I can tell you is from my own point of view the heart-breaking pain I felt, Iaposd never felt pain like it and it was like I could not breathe and my world had crashed into a million pieces.  Sadly, a lot of families go through this journey leading to their diagnosis. Another reason why knowledge, awareness, training and earlier diagnosis is so important. Myeloma is an incurable blood cancer that occurs in the bone marrow. It currently affects more than , people in the UK. On average,  people are diagnosed with Myeloma every day in the UK. Alyson said: My dad had fallen sick in October  and despite many tests ran nothing came to light. Even a few weeks before May st, Dad had more tests done and still nothing had shown up, even in the blood tests for cancer. Going back through my dadaposs medical history it is now thought that his myeloma could go back  years when it was at the apossmoulderingapos stage but right up to him being hospitalised nothing ever came to light. The myeloma had remained undetected. Another reason why a better diagnosis system needs to be found. Despite being told he had just days to live, Brian went home in July - a day that Alyson says is one they never thought we would see. Brian is said to have responded well to chemotherapy - but the damage done to his body cannot be reversed. He is on chemotherapy every day to give him some extra time. Another dficult side to Myeloma is that it does y from person to person and besides the cancer, myeloma can come with many other complications. For my dad it is his heart and lungs. Now Alyson and husband Alan, who run Alan Yates Music, are planning to do weekly gigs throughout March this year in a bid to fund the research into a cure for Myeloma.Alyson is immunocompromised, meaning her immune system is extremely weak and she is at higher risk of contracting Covid-.Myeloma may become curable but funds are required for that and funds are required to help those in today’s society where there isnapost a cure, she said. She said she wanted to support Myeloma UK to help fund research into a cure and to raise awareness of Myeloma so “it doesn’t happen to anybody . We went through a horrendous journey as a family and the thought of another family going through that… I just can’t”. Myeloma UK is the only organisation in the UK exclusively dedicated to Myeloma and its related conditions. They rely almost entirely on voluntary donations and fundraising. Their ultimate goal is to find a cure for Myeloma and until then aim to help every patient live well with the diagnosis for as long as possible.To find out more about myeloma and the work of Myeloma UK click here. news uk-news meghan-markle-silenced-pals-royal-"Meghan Markle made political wedding choices says expertByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsMeghan Markle reportedly made a subtle dig at le within the royal family during a speech to guests on her wedding day. The Duchess of Sussex is said to have made a comment about the royal le she was about to embark on, in front of her new family at her wedding to Prince Harry in . In their unofficial biography, Finding Freedom, Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand highlighted how Meghan hadn’t spoken in public before their big day. According to the authors of the book, it was a first for a royal bride and reinforced the notion that she is no typical duchess. They wrote: A first for a royal bride, the move reinforced the idea that this American was no typical duchess.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.aposYou could literally hear a pin dropapos, said a close confidant, who described the speech as a momentous occasion even for the Americans. aposFor her to have been quiet for as long as she had, and then have this really safe space where she could give these heartfelt remarks, it was a really special momentapos, the source said. aposShe spent so many years, whether on campus, on TV, or advocating for women to be empowered, speaking out. And sheaposs respected that. aposShe does have a lot of respect for the family and the institution that she has joined. Bit itaposs just a dferent way of living. Weaposd missed hearing her speakapos. And apparently Meghan felt the same way, because she laughed, aposI know itaposs been a whileapos. During her speech, the new Duchess of Sussex thanked the Queen for welcoming her into the family with open arms and Prince Charles for stepping in at the last minute and walking her down the aisle. According to Us Weekly, it was also believed that she made reference to her orce from Trevor Engelson, and affirmed that finding love was worth the wait. She went on to brand Prince Harry as the one. As time went on, Meghan settled into her role in the royal family and got used to the expectation to remain quiet. However, it has reportedly been dficult for her to adapt, as an insider claimed she was heard muttering donapost I have a voice during an engagement with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: mum who paid 1500 new
story: Mum who paid £, for new iPhone  max pro gutted to receive £ hand soap insteadMum Khaoula Lafhaily, , from north London, says the delivery driver told her he was "stuck in traffic" but then never showed up. Days later a dferent driver turned up but with a £ bottle of soap instead of her £ iPhone  Pro MaxSky says an investigation has been launched after a bottle of soap was delivered instead of the iPhone  pro max Image: Khaoula Lafhaily   SWNSByLauren BeavisRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Feb  A mum was left shocked after a delivery driver turned up with a £ bottle of hand soap instead of her £ new iPhone  max pro. Khaoula Lafhaily, , bought the gadget from Sky Mobile and the company dutully dispatched it via post.It was supposed to be delivered next day by DPD, but she said the driver then contacted her to say he was aposstuck in trafficapos,. Two days later a man dropped off a package - but when she opened it up there was only a refill bottle of blue hand soap wrapped up inside. The mum-of-one paid £ upfront and signed a  month contract, costing a total of £,. Khaoula from north London called Sky Mobile and claims they launched an investigation immediately - but more than a week on sheaposs still without a phone or answers. She said: We live in a first-floor flat, so have to watch out the window when we get deliveries otherwise they get delivered to the wrong flat. We saw the driver pull up to our house, take a photo from outside the house, then leave. But the driver told us that he came to the door, knocked and no one was there so he would againthe next day but we were watching at the window - it was a complete lie! A dferent delivery driver came on Thursday, my husband went down to collect the parcel at .am, which we opened at around midday because I was asleep - and it was a bottle of hand soap. Can you imagine  I was in complete shock and really need the phone. Itaposs definitely been stolen - itaposs awful.  She bought the phone on January  and paid for next day delivery, she said. The driver didnapost turn up but messaged to say he was stuck in traffic, so he said he wouldthe next day. On January  the driver ed but again failed to deliver the iPhone - he only took a photo of the front door and left again, without knocking or leaving the parcel, she claims. The next day a dferent driver dropped off the soap, she said, without asking for ID. Sky and DPD didnapost respond to a request for comment. title: national lottery voucher offer deal
story: Get a £ voucher* for the UKs best attractions using a National Lottery ticketYou can use a Lotto ticket to claim a £ voucher* to redeem when booking any one of hundreds of attractionsAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Whether you’re eight or , exploring new places brings out the adventurer inside us all. And in the UK we’re spoiled for choice, with hundreds of incredible attractions to fire up the imagination. Thrill seekers of all ages will find adrenaline-filled rides at Zip World or Legoland. Those who prefer a more relaxing experience can enjoy autumn’s spectacular show of colours at venues like Kew Gardens, Cardf Castle or RHS Garden Bridgewater – a major horticultural project near Salford. History fans will adore a trip to the gothic ruins at Whitby Abbey, Warwick or Stirling Castle, while animal lovers can meet Ruby the red panda, born in July at Edinburgh Zoo, or three adorable tiger cubs at Highland Wildle Park. Click here toabout National Lottery Days Out and redeem your £ voucher*. And you can use a Lotto ticket purchased on or after October ,  to claim a £ voucher* to redeem when booking any one of hundreds of attractions. Not only will you enjoy a discounted day trip, you can feel proud that you’ve helped fund many of the tourist and heritage sites that make the UK unique. By playing The National Lottery, you raise £million for good causes every week.  National Lottery players have supported  of the top  most visited tourist attractions in the UK**, from castles to wildle parks, botanical gardens to museums and plenty of other fun stuff. Every adventure starts with a finger on a map. So where will yours land Highland Wildle Park: Meet animals from all over the world  Get up close to some endangered animals from the world’s mountains and tundra in the stunning setting of the Cairngorms National Park. From the comfort of your car you’ll encounter bison, elk and red deer – then visit the tigers and polar bears on foot using the park’s trails. Many nativeanimals are here too, including the capercaillie, European grey wolf, wolverine, lynx, Scottish wildcat and beavers.Cardf Castle: Enjoy a great day in history It has a history that stretches back to Roman times, a keep dating from the Norman Conquest, a spectacular moat and great views over the city that sits just beside it. Cardf Castle makes for one brilliant family day out. You’ll learn that it was once home to the world’s richest man, and was used as a giant air raid shelter during the Nazi bombardment of the city. Kids will love standing beside the huge replica trebuchet – a six-ton medieval weapon built for a movie that was filmed at the castle. After you’ve toured the building, stroll around its beautul grounds, or explore the city itself.Stonehenge: Explore this wonderful World Heritage Site Get close to this mysterious monument that dates back nearly , years. This awe-inspiring embodiment of human ingenuity offers a direct connection to our ancient past, and is a bucket-list destination for visitors around the world. Click here toabout the National Lottery Days Out and redeem your £ voucher*.  *Subject to availability. One voucher per person. + only. See NationalLotteryDaysOut for full TsCs.**Source: the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions, . news uk-news prince-harrys-super-private-cousin-"Louis Spencer arrives at Prince Harry and Meghan Markles Royal weddingByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Feb |commentsPrinces William and Harry have a host of well-known cousins who live their lives in the spotlight. But they also have some who lead very private lives - including a younger cousin, who is set to one day inherit Princess Dianaaposs ,-acre family estate, despite having three older sisters.Louis Spencer, also known as Viscount Althorp, is the oldest son of Earl Spencer, the brother of Princess Diana.He was born in  in Cape Town and has three older sisters Lady Kitty Spencer, Lady Amelia Spencer and Lady Eliza Spencer. Louis, who went to the University of Edinburgh, is reportedly close to both William and Harry, despite him being a fair few years their junior.  The -year-old has been described as apossuper privateapos as well as aposdecent and kindapos.Heaposs even been dubbed apos Prince Harry liteapos and was once called one of the worldaposs most eligible bachelors.A friend of Louis told the : He’s super private and gets on quietly with his thing. He’s a very talented actor and, I think, will be a brilliant one. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. You’d like him. He’s very low-key and genuine, decent and kind – and tall. His status as the eldest son of Earl Spencer will see him one day inherit the Grade I-listed stately home of Althorp House in Northamptonshire and the earldom. And itaposs believed he has already started getting ready to take over and has been to a number of trusteesapos meetings. Measuring , sq ft, Althorp House boasts  rooms and a portrait gallery. Following Dianaaposs death in  she was buried on a small island on the wider estate in the middle of the ornamental Round Oval lake.  Although the monarchy has now changed to put sons and daughters on an equal footing in terms of ascending to the throne, British primogeniture law has not been changed for peers such as dukes and earls.This means Louis will inherit Althorp rather than his oldest sister Kitty, who married -year-old businessman Michael Lewis in a grand ceremony in Italy last year.In a previous interview, Kitty, , said: Primogeniture can be a tricky topic because as times are changing, attitudes are as well. Weaposve grown up understanding that itaposs Louis to inherit, and Louis will do an incredible job. Meanwhile, her father Earl Spencer suggested it would go against the tradition of Althorp House to overlook his son. He said in : I would be totally relaxed about Kitty inheriting it, but...I chose Kitty it would be against all the tradition that goes with Althorp. title: push identify brit dubbed gentleman
story: Push to identy Brit dubbed the Gentleman found off coast of Germany  years agoThe mystery man, thought to be British and aged between  and , was wearing distinctive size  handmade luxury English shoes and a woollen tie. He was washed up off HeligolandAn artist reconstruction of the mystery man Image: HandoutByTom PettorCrime Editor:,  Feb |commentsBritish experts have appealed for help identying a ft in suspected murder victim dubbed The Gentleman who was found off the German coast  years ago. The mystery man, thought to be British and aged between  and , was wearing distinctive size  handmade luxury English shoes and a woollen tie. He was washed up off Heligoland, a small archipelago on the north-west coast of Germany, on July , . The man had died up to seven months earlier, had injuries to his head and upper body and had been weighed down by his suspected killer or killers. Forensic psychologists from Goldsmiths, University of London, the University of Staffordshire and Plymouth Marjon University have been drafted in to try and identy him. Fiona Gabbert, Professor of Psychology and Director of the Forensic Psychology Unit at Goldsmiths, said: “We believe that the man is likely to have gone missing somewhere between the end of  and the first six months of  so we’re calling on the public to think back to that time. “Our research shows that activating memories from a particular period can help iniduals remember more information from that particular time so we’re asking you to read through a list of news and events that happened in  . “Take a while to think where you were and who you knew at this time. Do you think you might know the man we are seeking to identy ” Top stories at the time included the death of Pablo Escobar , the IRA Heathrow bombings, the death of Nirvana singer Kurt Cobain, O.J. Simpson’s arrest and the inauguration of Nelson Mandela as President of South Africa. The man was slim, weighing around  to  stone. His hair colour andand eye colour are all unknown. He was from an English-speaking area so may have been British or had links to Britain.His black or navy leather loafers were made by upmarket shoemakers Church Co Limited.They had been re-soled with Philipps soles and had replacement heels manufactured by Dinky Heel PLC, Bristol, with the inscription I.T.S. Jubilee and a stylised crown. He was wearing a % wool tie which was dark blue with grey, brown, orange and green diagonal stripes. The tie’s label included instructions in English and French to dry clean only. His navy trousers were made in France and he was wearing a long-sleeved, light blue shirt with collar. His body may have been thrown off a ship off Heligoland or entered from Heligoland and moved out to sea. The German authorities are being supported in the UK by charity Locate International. title: retired british airways jet bought
story: Retired British Airways jet bought for £ transformed into £,-an-hour party planeThe British Airways Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space to host everything from private birthday parties to product launches and corporate eventsThe BA Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space Image: @negus   SWNSByTom Bevan:,  Feb  A classic  British Airways jet has undergone a dramatic transformation into a “party plane” which will be available for revellers to hire.The BA Negus jet has been remodelled into an events space to host everything from private birthday parties to product launches and corporate events, and is now sitting pretty at the privately-owned Cotswolds Airport near Wiltshire. It was bought for just £ in  by the airportaposs chief executive Suzannah Harvey when British Airways retired its fleet early due to the pandemic, and has been a labor of love ever since. Suzannah said: I paid a pound for her, and we have a certain obligation to maintain it as is practical for public use. The company has had to spend nearly £, getting her prepped and ready here, but I think itaposs money well spent and it preserves her for future generations.  Most of the original structure has stayed the same but the transformation has included stripping out the economy section to create the events space and turning the gallery into a bar. A full rewiring with custom lighting has been done while it also took one man a whole week and a half to give it a good clean inside and out. Suzannah described the renovation process as a “long old slog”.  “She came into us in October , and at the time I rather naively thought weaposd have her up and running by the following Easter,” she said. Weaposve had such tremendous support from everybody. All the contractors, all the people that have volunteered who are current BA  engineers - and here we are finally. “Sheaposs ready and sheaposs good to go. The Negus entered the British Airways fleet on  February , operating , flights - flying for , hours over nearly  million miles.  Its last passenger flight was from Miami to Heathrow on  April, .Anyone now wanting to host a party onboard will have to pay more than £, an hour but Suzannah said they had been inundated with enquiries - including from Netflix.Suzannah added: The vision has finally come to fruition, with overwhelming support from volunteers including current BA engineers and half a million pounds of investment later, Negus  is finally ready.  Preserved for many years to come and future generations, Negus is the only bespoke events  in the world. Cotswold Airport is family owned and operated and is the largest privately owned airport in Europe having a runway only m shorter than Bristol International. Suzannah said an app will soon be launched to enable the general public to book tours of the aircraft. news uk-news royals-most-wacky-requests-elaborate-"Prince Andrew: Former royal bodyguard discusses teddiesByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Feb Being a royal often means that the people around you and those you meet are eager to please.So chances areyouaposre a royal and you ask for something - no matter how wacky - itaposs likely you will get it. And although members of the Firm are mainly very polite when it comes to dealing with their staff, there are quirky and sometimes bizarre requests that they make. From elaborate bath routines to very specic sandwiches - here we take a look at some of them... Prince Charlesapos bath demands Prince Charles has a team of staff, who also help out with his very strict and somewhat unusual morning routine - that sets him up for the day ahead.  An insight into his routine was once revealed by Princess Dianaaposs friend and former butler Paul Burrell, who worked closely with the family in the s.Speaking during Amazon Primeaposs documentary Serving the Royals: Inside the Firm, Mr Burrell revealed: His pyjamas are pressed every morning and his shoe laces are pressed flat with an iron. And when it comes to his morning bath, Mr Burrell added that the prince also has some very specic requests. He also told the documentary: The water temperature has to be just tepid, and only half full.” The ex-butler also added that the bath plug must face specic direction, his bath towel must be arranged to his taste and his underwear can’t be a crease out of place. Queenaposs round sandwiches  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Afternoon tea is a luxury that the royals, including the Queen, often like to indulge in.But according to one former royal chef, the Queen only ate her sandwichesthey were cut in a particular way - with no points.According to Hello!, instead she is served small jam penny sandwiches with afternoon tea.Speaking on the documentary Secrets of the Royal Kitchen, chef Graham Newbould said: The royals never have square sandwiches because tradition has it that anyone presenting them with pointed-edged food is trying to overthrow the throne of England. Prince Andrewaposs teddy bears A former royal protection officer claimed that Prince Andrew has a very specic set up of his cuddly toys. It is said that the Duke of York sketched out a plan for how his five teddies and cuddly toys should be positioned on his bed every night. The toys are said to include two hippos, a black panther and bears, as well as three cushions called aposDaddyapos, aposDucksapos and aposPrinceapos. The sketch allegedly shows exactly where to place blankets, as well as five toys and a fur, which had ribbons that had to hang off the side of the bed. The instructions were laminated and titled “DOY bed: Points for turn down  making the bed”, with Andrew said to keep the accompanying sketch close to his bed while staying at Buckingham Palace. Charlesapos breakfast request  Another unusual request when it comes to eating breakfast is by Prince Charles.According to former royal chef Darren McGrady, the heir to the throne would always ask for two plums with breakfast - but only eat one, reports MyLondon.McGrady said: The instruction was to put two plums and a little juice into the bowl and send it into him for breakfast. Iaposd send in two plums and he would take one so it would come back out after breakfast and Iaposd put the other plum back into the jar and save it. The former chef continued: One morning I thought, aposok, he only eats one for breakfast,apos so I only put one plum into the bowl and sent it out into the dining room. The attending [waiter] came through and said, aposcan His Royal Highness have two please apos So I had to keep sending two in every morning. Kateaposs name plea Although not strictly a royal at the time as she was not yet married to Prince William, the Duchess of Cambridge once issued a bizarre request.Kateaposs proper first name is Catherine, but became known as Kate while at St Andrews University. Even though her full name is Catherine, his university girlfriend became known as Kate as the world ponderedshe would be our future Queen.However, it was been reported she wasnapost actually a fan of the name aposKateapos and even emailed her friends in , two years before her engagement, asking them to call her Catherine instead.Writing for the Sunday Express at the time, columnist Adam Helliker said: With Prince William’s engagement now a surefire certaintythere are intriguing signs that Kate Middleton is preparing for her future role. It looks like she’s taking it very seriously indeed too. I hear that in the past few weeks the former accessories buyer has quietly informed friends that she would like to drop the informal ‘Kate’ and in future wishes to be known by her full name: aposCatherineapos. title: schoolgirl 11 half blonde half
story: Schoolgirl, , has half blonde and half brown hair due to rare genetic birthmarkMum Jenny Hill, from Lincoln, was stunned when -year-old Bella was born with a head of half blonde and half brunette hair and she says she is constantly quizzed on whether she dyes itBella Hill can decide whether she wants to be blonde or brunette every morning Image: Kennedy News and MediaByHannah PhillipsLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A schoolgirl can decide whether she wants to be blonde or brunette every morning thanks to a rare genetic aposbirthmarkapos that causes her hair to be two dramatically dferent colours. Mum Jenny Hill, from Lincoln, was stunned when -year-old Bella was born with a head of half blonde and half brunette hair.Since then, gobsmacked passersby admire her hair and constantly quiz her about whether she dyes it or not. Student nurse Jenny, , believes that the distinctive trait is caused by poliosis, which creates a lack of pigment in a patch of hair. The schoolgirl even has dferent coloured eyelashes - her right lashes are a light colour while her left ones are dark. Bellaaposs unique barnet means that every morning she can decide whether she wants to embrace her blonde or brunette side depending on the parting - making the decision based on her outfit. Jenny, from Lincoln, Lincolnshire, said: Itaposs really dferent and unique. My mum pointed it out when she was born but at the time I was in too much pain to notice. She was saying sheaposs fair and I said sheaposs dark then we noticed her eyelashes were fair on the blonde side and dark on the brunette side. I asked about it at her six-week check-up and they kind of just said aposoh yesapos and didnapost make a big deal out of it. As parents itaposs more noticeable because you stare at your baby but itaposs more prominent as sheaposs got older. In the summer the darker side does go fairer. The blonde is an ice blonde, like itaposs been bleached and it goes all the way underneath in an unusual pattern. If she has it in a certain style, sheaposs blonde butshe changes her parting, sheaposs brunette. She prefers her hair lighter when she wears more girly clothes and pastel colours but when she wears her hoodies and joggers, she wears it up so itaposs dark. Bella said: I donapost really have a favourite shade, it depends what outfit Iaposm wearing. A lot of school friends do want my hair and some askI dye it. The mum-of-three suspects the rare feature is caused by poliosis as neither of her other children, Riley,  or Lilah, four, have inherited it. Jenny admits that Bellaaposs unique aposdo garners a lot of attention with strangers askingthey colour her hair. Others joke that Jenny aposmust have inhaled a lot of bleachapos while working as a hairdresser when pregnant with her. Jenny said: We got a lot of attention when she was little. It would take us hours to get round the supermarket because people would stop and admire Bellaaposs hair or askweaposd dyed it. I was a hairdresser when I was pregnant with Bella so it was a running joke that maybe Iaposd been around the bleach too much. A lot of people donapost notice her eyelashes but itaposs obvious when you look at her. She gets told by everyone that she isnapost allowed to touch her hair. Weaposve only ever seen similar hair once. We were in the supermarket once and we saw another boy with a patch of hair like Bellaaposs. It was really exciting. Bella pointed him out and said aposheaposs got hair like meapos so we went over because we havenapost seen anyone  before. title: school makes parents sign contract
story: School makes parents sign contract to say homosexuality is a sin - or will expel kidsThe contract is lumping students who are unsure about their sexuality or unsure about their gender identity... with the likes paedophiles and adulterersFormer Citipointe Christian College student Felicity Myers Image: AAP PA ImagesByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA school has sparked outrage after asking parents to sign a contract saying that homosexuality is a sin or their child will be expelled. Despite the backlash, headteacher Brian Mulheran, of the Citipointe Christian College, has doubled down and given parents an extra two weeks to sign their children up. The contract was sent to families last Friday and said the college will only enrol the student on the basis of the gender that corresponds to their biological sex. It also asserted that homosexuality, along with bestiality, incest and paedophilia, was sinful. One teacher, who also has a student at the college, has already resigned saying young people within the LGBTQ+ community deserve to feel safe while at school. Helen Clapham Burns was also a teacher at the school in Carindale, Australia, but quit on Monday saying she couldnapost continue to work for a school that would do that to children.  Mrs Burns said: Iaposm heartbroken. I feel like Iaposve let them down that Iaposm having to leave. But I have to let those queer kids know that there are Christians out there that love them and arenapost hiding behind Bible verses and are letting them know that they are safe with me. As an educator, my priority is to make sure that each child that I interact with feels safe. When a child tells us, with tears in their eyes, that they donapost feel safe, what are we doing  Mr Mulheran made a video for parents about the contract. In it he said he had listened to their concerns and wanted them to make the right decisions for themselves. The declaration of faith has been in place for the whole of last year, he said.  We want families to consider this ethos so that they can make the right decisions for themselves. He added: We have always held these Christian beliefs and we have tried to be fair and transparent to everyone in our community by making them clear in the enrolment contract. We are seeking to maintain our Christian ethos and to give parents and students the right to make an informed choice about whether they can support and embrace our approach to Christian education. Citipointe does not judge students on their sexuality or gender identity and we would not make a decision about their enrolment in the College simply on that basis.  A group of parents has said they want to file a complaint to the Human Rights Commission, arguing they were not consulted about the contract and that the college was discriminating against students on the basis of sexuality and gender identity. One parent who is asked not to be named said: The contract they put out is so blatantly damaging to anyone within the school who identies within the LGBTQI umbrella are not of their highest concern. But nor is anybody  who believes in standing up against this kind of discrimination, because the contract makes it clear that any kind of act that goes against this belief is something that can be disciplined. Federal Member for Moncref, Angie Bell, told ABC Radio in Brisbane she disagreed with the college lumping students who are unsure about their sexuality or unsure about their gender identity ... with the likes paedophiles and adulterers. No school child should be discriminated against based on their sexual orientation, their gender identity, their pregnancy status, or their relationship status, which are the four elements that are in that section of the Sex Discrimination Act, she said.Religious organisations also have the right to practise their faith … without a doubt … notitaposs done in a discriminatory fashion. This is not  anymore … this is a new year, this is a new decade, this is a new Australia and there is no room. news uk-news terried-meghan-markles-telling-comment-"Meghan Markle and Harry’s trademarks have ‘intricate meanings’ says expertByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments From an aspiring actress to the Duchess of Sussex, Meghan Markle is no stranger to the spotlight. But when she started dated one of the worldaposs most eligible bachelors, Prince Harry, she was determined to keep things quiet while she worked outhe was The One.The couple successfully kept their relationship a secret for five months, flying between Canada and London to see each other, enjoying cosy nights in at his Kensington Palace cottage. But they knew it was only a matter of time before their perfect, private bubble burst. When news that Harry had been secretly dating the Suits star was leaked, they had only a few hours to prepare before it appeared on the front pages.  But the realisation that this was aposher new leapos, terried Meghan, claims royal journalists, Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand. In their unofficial biography Finding Freedom, the authors share details of what happened on the night the couple were told their time in hiding was up.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. They wrote: One night late in October in Toronto, Harry was happy, and so was Meghan. Until their received a call from one of Harryaposs aides at Kensington Palace. It wasnapost good news. A tabloid was going to run with the story of their relationship. Their main worry was that her place would be besieged by photographers within  hours. They had little time to think because there was only a couple of paparazzi in Toronto but it wouldnapost be long before photographers flew in from New York and LA, all hoping to get that first picture of the happy couple. Harry was inundated with calls from staff who encouraged him toto London as soon as possible since he had a smaller security team than normal. But, he refused to leave. Scobie and Durand claim that while Meghan was nervous about what was to come, she was relieved that the secrecy and lies to friends and family would be coming to an end. They said: Prior to meeting Harry, the only times she experiences cameras were on a set or on a red carpet. The security was necessary. Shortly after the news broke, a photographer from an LA-based photo agency had scaled the fence into her back garden and waited for Meghan by her car, hoping to get a picture before she headed out to run errands. Meghan was terried and called the police. aposThis is how itaposs always going to be, isnapost it apos, she said to a friend.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it.
